Authors:
Cathrine Sumathi Manohar, Teun Boekhout, Wally H Muller,
Thorsten Stoeck
Title:
Tritirachium candoliense sp. nov., a novel basidiomycetous
fungus isolated from the anoxic zone of the Arabian Sea
Keywords:
Marine, anoxic, Arabian Sea, fungi, Basidiomycota,
Tritirachium condoliense,
Abstract:
A highly divergent fungal culture, FCAS11 was isolated
from the marine, coastal sediments of the Arabian Sea during anoxic
season. This culture is described in this study as a novel species,
based on its growth characteristics, morphological, ultra structural
features and phylogenetic analyses. The growth characteristics and
nutritional utilization efficiency investigated shows that the culture
has slow growth under anoxic condition.The SEM images of the fungal
mycelia shows that it produces very few blastocondia and distortment of
major ultrastructural features such as the mitrochondria, fat globules
and cell wall could also be observed from TEM images. Phylogenetic
analyses based on the multiple genes which included the small subunit
(SSU), internal transcribed spacer region (ITS) and large subunit (LSU)
of the nuclear rDNA, translation elongation factor 1α (EF1α) and DNA
directed RNA polymerase II subunit 2 (RPB2) was carried out. Phylograms
were also constructed from individual datasets belonging to the SSU,
LSU, EF1α and RPB2 gene seqeunces. These results place the isolate as a
novel species within the newly defined class Tritirachiomycetes, within
Pucciniomycotina phylum Basidiomycota. Analyses including only the
members of this class based on the ITS sequence was also carried out to
study the placement of this isolate with a higher resolution. It also
supports the results that the taxa is a new species and is different
from any of the known taxa within Tritirachiomycetes with good bootstrap
support from both the ML and NJ analysis. Description of FCAS11 is the
first report of fungal taxa belonging to class Tritirachiomycetes from
the marine environment. We propose to call this new species as
Tritirachium candoliense sp. nov., after the place from where it was
isolated.
